intro: Hydrobryum olivaceum, commonly known as the olive-green marsh plant, is a member of the Cyperaceae family, commonly referred to as the sedge family. It is a perennial herb that typically grows in wetland environments, such as marshes and along the edges of ponds. The plant features narrow, grass-like leaves and produces small, spike-like inflorescences that contain numerous tiny flowers. Its flowers are usually greenish or yellowish in color, and it relies on wind pollination. Hydrobryum olivaceum plays an important ecological role in stabilizing wetland soils and providing habitat for various aquatic and terrestrial organisms.
